body: @bhaisaab Indeed, let's fix forward when needed :-) There's always a risk, but I'm happy to see this work being done :+1:
I am alright with this. I was curious if @mike-tutkowski is.

@bhaisaab Wrote a script to handle the merge and made it compatible with your 'git pr' workflow. 

See https://github.com/schubergphilis/cloudstack-git-tree-manipulation/blob/master/git-pr
Put 'git-pr' script in $PATH (and disable/rename your 'pr' alias). I'm finalising the script based on feedback I got and will send a PR soon to add it to ACS repo. 
Docs are being written here: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=61311655

Let me know if it makes sense.
@milamberspace Could you please close this PR as @bhaisaab applied the patch to 4.5. Thanks!

I know, but he has been busy on this as well, are we in a hurry? On squashing: I agree with the observation that this is one of those exceptions where squashing indeed makes sense. The two actual structural changes (the first two commits) seem identical. The rest are fixes of the changed code.

80bcfb1 and  af199e7 are not atomic then?

I did not send a :-1: to dev@. I did not omit that mail by mistake (sorry for the double negative). the proposal seems radical (17 july is phased out on 17  August) but house cleaning is needed. let's make a PR like this on a weekly basis.
@DaanHoogland Weekly basis is OK with me!

Now, I am having troubles again with squash.

I am using this command “git rebase -i HEAD~2” to squash the last to commits into one. The git prompts me a screen in which I can change commits comments and return “Successfully rebased and updated”. Then, I try to push using “git push –f” to force the remote repository to accept my push. The git answers “Everything up-to-date” , however commits are not getting squashed into remote. 
Am I doing something wrong?
[cloudstack-pull-analysis #252](https://builds.apache.org/job/cloudstack-pull-analysis/252/) ABORTED
[cloudstack-pull-analysis #253](https://builds.apache.org/job/cloudstack-pull-analysis/253/) ABORTED
@DaanHoogland You are right. I squashed to commits together so there will not be a non-working commit left.
[cloudstack-pull-analysis #254](https://builds.apache.org/job/cloudstack-pull-analysis/254/) ABORTED

@rafaelweingartner if you git rebase -i HEAD~2 and have $EDITOR set to something usable you will get and editor with instructions something like:

```
pick fa7f8cf @rafaelweingartner     Had a problem while squashing @cristofolini commits, for some odd reason
pick 3937e7b    removed trailing whitespace

# Rebase #######..######## onto ####### (       2 TODO item(s))
#
# Commands:
# p, pick = use commit
# r, reword = use commit, but edit the commit message
# e, edit = use commit, but stop for amending
# s, squash = use commit, but meld into previous commit
# f, fixup = like "squash", but discard this commit's log message
# x, exec = run command (the rest of the line) using shell
#
# These lines can be re-ordered; they are executed from top to bottom.
#
# If you remove a line here THAT COMMIT WILL BE LOST.
#
# However, if you remove everything, the rebase will be aborted.
#
# Note that empty commits are commented out
```

On the second line replace pick with f or s. if you choose s you get the change to change the commit message, which in this case I would change to "Removed duplicate code in CitrixResourceBase and subclasses". If you do use s a second editor will come.

Holly S...
I am so sorry, when I got that screen with the text I was not even reading it, I thought it was just the comments on each commit, and that git was giving me the opportunity to change it. I did not realize that I had to say what it should to commits.

Now, everything seems ok.
